snippet: Egypt’s military crackdown has left President Obama in a no-win position: risk a partnership that has been the bedrock of Middle East peace, or stand by while allies try to hold on to power by mowing down opponents.
abstract: Violent crackdown by Egypt's military leaves Pres Obama in a no-win position; Obama can either risk partnership with Egypt that has been the bedrock of Middle East peace, or stand by while allies try to hold to power by mowing down opponents; American officials had tried every tool to avert bloodshed, but effort ultimately failed as Egypt's military concluded rightly that it would not pay significant cost if it took action against protesters.

byline.original: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK, PETER BAKER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
byline.contributor: David D. Kirkpatrick reported from Cairo, and Peter Baker and Michael R. Gordon from Washington. Reporting was contributed by Eric Schmitt, Mark Mazzetti and Thom Shanker from Washington; Mark Landler from Chilmark, Mass.; and Steven Erlanger from London.

lead_paragraph: Egypt’s military crackdown has left President Obama in a no-win position: risk a partnership that has been the bedrock of Middle East peace, or stand by while allies try to hold on to power by mowing down opponents.

headline.main: How American Hopes for a Deal in Egypt Were Undercut
headline.print_headline: How A U.S. Push To Defuse Egypt Ended In Failure

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
keywords.name: subject
